data.title: Deterministic Component Init and Update Order

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

Right now, Components are initialized and shut down on a per-GameObject basis. This should be changed in favor of a per-Component-Type approach to mirror the new Update order based on Component types.
#### Analysis
- This affects `Activate` / `Deactivate` and `Loaded` / `Saving` / `Saved`.
- In some cases, a single object or set of objects will require initialization or shutdown outside the regular Scene-switch case. Always consider the current group of objects when determining the order of initialization and shutdown.

data.title: Weird Behaviour when Moving Objects in the Scene View

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

This issue was first reported on the forum by user **indiemaatheus**: [Forum Topic](http://forum.adamslair.net/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=733)

> Hey, recently I noticed that something weird is happening when dragging and dropping objects in the scene, it was not happening before. I just have no clue what I'm doing wrong, see:
> [Image](http://i.imgur.com/yKM5O4o.gif)
> Instead of following the mouse, the sprite starts moving extremely fast in its direction. (surprised/confused face here)
> What should I do?
#### How to reproduce

Just place an object into a scene and try dragging it around. The object should move weirdly, and a lot of error messages should be written to the log.

This issue seems prevalent on the latest Duality binary release. Versions built from source seems to not have the problem. **indiemaatheus** uploaded a sample project ([Dropbox](https://db.tt/WQabs6OP)), but as said before, the problems seem to occur even in the binary release (from [the Duality website](http://duality.adamslair.net/)).
#### Workaround

No workarounds are known, except to use a version built from the source code.
#### Attachments
- An error occurs and is written to the log when moving objects: [Pastebin](http://pastebin.com/raw/CYuQhecV)
- An animated GIF image was uploaded by **indiemaatheus**, available here: [Image](http://i.imgur.com/yKM5O4o.gif)

milestone.title: General

data.body:
#### Summary

Right now, there is no way to investigate the full Undo / Redo stack, even though certain editor modules do require this kind of access. This is a dependency of issue #278 and #296.
#### Analysis
- Exposing the Undo / Redo stack will lead to users making assumptions on its consistency and content. The API should be designed in a way that it is clear what to rely on (Action IDs?) and what not to (The stack being unlimited / an action never being removed from it, etc.)

data.title: Full instead of Additive PackageConfig.xml Sync

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

If a user manually modifies his `PackageConfig.xml` without adjusting the local `Source\Packages` cache accordingly, all previously unknown packages and versions will be installed additively. Older versions will not be removed, but should be. This can be an issue in a multi-user version control setup, where only `PackageConfig.xml` is part of version control, but not `Source\Packages`.
#### Analysis
- It's probably sufficient to extend the [FirstTimeSetup](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/blob/master/DualityEditor/Program.cs#L122) method in the editor main program.
  - Before verifying all packages, there should be an additional step where unlisted packages are uninstalled.
  - Be very careful here: _Only_ uninstall Duality packages, since all others will not be listed in `PackageConfig` anyway.
  - Also make sure uninstalling a package before the verification step doesn't have side effects, such as removing the uninstalled package from the verification list inadvertently.
- This feature needs thorough testing before being released, as it affects the update mechanism itself. Don't do a rush-release on this one.

data.title: Add Code Analyzers to Duality Core Source

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

Switch the main development repository of Duality to Visual Studio 2015 to gain access to the new Analyzer feature and add some Analyzers to reduce reviewing workload on Pull Requests. This should not affect the minimum required version to develop plugins with Duality, only developing Duality itself will be upgraded. The framework version should not be changed.
#### Analysis
- Visual Studio 2015 should provide access to the [Analyzers](http://www.dotnetcurry.com/visualstudio/1197/diagnostic-analyzers-visual-studio-2015) feature
- Code Analyzer availability is probably the main benefit of switching to VS 2015. This will allow to enforce coding style and other development guidelines and reduce the code review workload for new contributions.
- For Duality plugins, nothing should be changed. Users can switch versions as they prefer and compatibility should be a bigger concern. VS 2015 is still comparatively new and there is no good reason to enforce this as a minspec for framework users.
- Before doing this, make sure AppVeyor is able to compile Visual Studio 2015 projects and solutions. _Edit:_ It's [probably installed](https://www.appveyor.com/docs/installed-software#visual-studio-2015).

data.title: Investigate Editor / WinForms Re-Entrancy Problems with Task Parallel Library

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
#### Summary

When using methods of the task parallel library, such as `Parallel.For`, the editor will pump a selective subset of windows messages while waiting for its completion. Among these events is WM_PAINT, which can cause re-entrancy problems when attempting to repaint the scene.
#### How to reproduce

Unclear. It happens occasionally - the more `Parallel.For` is used in the core, the higher the chance. Right now, there is no `Parallel.For` in the main update / render cycle because of the re-entrancy problems, but adding some for testing should reproduce this behavior easily.
#### Workaround

Avoid `Parallel.For` in the main update / render cycle. This is what's done currently.
#### Attachments
- [StackOverflow question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/35535580/why-does-parallel-for-execute-the-winforms-message-pump-and-how-to-prevent-it) on this.
- [ILSpy Disassembly](https://gist.github.com/ilexp/3076aa7f620351154a9a) of relevant .Net Implementations for synchronization contexts.

data.title: Rework Object Previews / PreviewProviders

milestone.title: v3.0
milestone.description: Everything that will be part of the major v3.0 Duality release.

data.body:
_The aim of this issue has shifted away from a distinct editor module and towards a (DualityEditor) preview panel control, which is incorporated in the Object Inspector (plugin). See the [first comment](https://github.com/AdamsLair/duality/issues/294#issuecomment-215986188) for more information._
#### Summary

Object previews are currently embedded directly into the Object Inspector. This leads to code duplication and needless limitations. Replace this concept with a new "Object Preview" editor module that simply displays a preview of the currently selected object(s).
#### Analysis
- With a custom (docking) editor module, previews can be adjusted by the user to fit any size, rather than being dependent on proprety editor sizes.
- It would be a lot easier for custom Resources to display a preview, since all that is needed is a custom `PreviewProvider`, which is a lot easier to write and more versatile, as it is also used by `ContentRef<T>` property editors, etc.
- A lot of custom PropertyEditor code could be removed or unified after implementing this.
  - `TexturePreviewPropertyEditor` / `TextureContentPropertyEditor` / `TexturePropertyEditor`
  - `PixmapPreviewPropertyEditor` / `PixmapContentPropertyEditor` / `PixmapPropertyEditor`
  - `FontPreviewPropertyEditor` / `FontContentPropertyEditor` / `FontPropertyEditor`
  - `AudioDataPreviewPropertyEditor` / `AudioDataPropertyEditor`
  - `ImagePreviewPropertyEditor`
- Releasing this package would also require releasing a new installer `.zip` package, since the list of default packages will have to be extended.
- Should multiple instances of an Object Preview module be allowed?
  - If yes, a selection coordination similar to the existing one in Object Inspector would be necessary.
  - If not, there will no longer be a convenient per-selection-group preview like currently in a multi-inspector situation.
  - Does this really add value? Questionable. Maybe limit to single-instance for now and extend later when needed.

The current way of importing Fonts into Duality is working, but quite limited and a bit buggy at times due to less-than-ideal Font handling in GDI+ / System.Drawing. A viable alternative would potentially improve usability and at the same time provide a sample on how to write custom Bitmap Font Importers.

Pick a commonplace bitmap font generator and implement a custom importer for it. Specifically, the [AngelCode Bitmap Font Generator](http://www.angelcode.com/products/bmfont/) looks quite good.

data.title: Implement Tilemap AutoTiles

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
As previously described in issue #249, the tilemaps plugin needs some kind of AutoTile feature. This feature will affect Tileset and editor implementations, but is mostly transparent towards Tilemaps themselves.
- There could actually be two distinct types of AutoTiles: "Invasive" AutoTiles (that actually generate new tiles internally) and "Non-Invasive" AutoTiles (that just automatically choose from a set of existing tiles depending on their surroundings).
- For editor convenience, it could be possible to specify additional tiles an AutoTile connects to.
- Also have a way to not use AutoTiling in specific cases, or use specific AutoTile-versions on mapper's choice, see [here](http://forums.rpgmakerweb.com/index.php?/topic/14387-shiftclick-mapping/).

As previously described in issue #249, the tilemaps plugin still needs a way to auto-generate RigidBody shapes from tilemaps.

data.title: Implement a Tilemap Minimap

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
As previously described in issue #249, the tilemaps editor plugin could use a minimap to keep an overview on the current scene for large maps.
- Displays all visible tilemaps of the current scene for context, and the currently selected one as primary one.
  - Each tilemap needs to be displayed the same as with a non-perspective / pure orthographic camera.
- Displays the current camera viewport and allows to drag it around.
- Reacts to changes in the scene to automatically update itself.
- The highest zoom level is one-pixel-per-tile, lower zoom levels are chosen in order to fit the current map into the minimap. The selected tilemap is used as reference for this.

data.title: Switch Duality's Path Separator

milestone.title: General
milestone.description: Improving the existing functionality of Duality without creating whole new modules or systems.

data.body:
With the new v2.0 platform abstraction, Duality uses it's own path strings that are (for the most part) platform-agnostic. The backend will then transform them back and forth transparently. (This approach is required because path strings are serialized on the development platform, but will then be used on various player platforms.)

The current choice of the platform-agnostic path separator as a Backslash rather than a Slash, however, is a bit unfortunate. This should be switched in the next major version step. It's actually a matter of two lines of code, but since it cannot be guaranteed that this won't break existing games and plugins, it seems better to wait with this.

data.title: Evaluate Editor UI Frameworks

milestone.title: Future
milestone.description: New systems and modules requiring a significant amount of long-term effort.

data.body:
While the current editor is in a very good state and WinForms is fine, it does have the major drawback of being Windows only - and Mono can't really fix this in a good way. 

This is a **long term** investigation. Neither do I plan to start implementing something anytime soon, nor do I currently have the resources to do so for a change on this scale - but it can't hurt to do some research.
## Required Traits
- **Cross-Platform** support for major desktop platforms: Windows, Linux, MacOS
- A versatile **Docking Control** like the DockPanelSuite that is currently used. Really, there is no way around this.
- An **OpenGL widget** that can be used to render the game somewhere in the editor.
- **High-DPI** awareness. (See issue #140)
## Desirable Traits
- Written primarily in **managed code / C#** - if it can be avoided, don't introduce natively compiled things into the otherwise managed Duality world.
- Being able to **deploy the same binaries** on all of the supported systems with runtime detection what backend to use - similar to the goal of Duality's cross platform support.
- Being able to **embed the UI framework** itself inside the game, allowing to use the same UI framework both ingame and in the editor - which would make developing editor plugins a lot more straightforward.
- **Separate style from structure**, providing proper skinning support.
- **Separate model from view**, hopefully making the overall UI code cleaner.

---

There is nothing wrong with WinForms or the current editor, and while there sure is room for improvement, a UI framework change would be a considerable effort that should not be decided easily. This issue is not about starting something, but about looking around what options there are for the long term future.
